description: Core PowerView cmdlets for Active Directory object enumeration (users, groups, computers)

commands.name: Get Domain Information (PowerView)
commands.description: Retrieve current domain information including forest, domain controllers, PDC, and domain properties using PowerView
failure_indicators: Get-NetDomain : The term 'Get-NetDomain' is not recognized

troubleshooting.Get-NetDomain not recognized: PowerView not imported. Import: Import-Module .\PowerView.ps1 or dot-source: . .\PowerView.ps1
troubleshooting.Access Denied: Not logged in as domain user. Verify: whoami /fqdn

commands.notes:
POWERVIEW SIMPLIFICATION:
Simplifies .NET LDAP queries into easy cmdlets.

EQUIVALENT TO:
  [System.DirectoryServices.ActiveDirectory.Domain]::GetCurrentDomain()

RETURNS CRITICAL PROPERTIES:
- PdcRoleOwner:
Target for enumeration
- DomainMode:
Functional level
- Forest:
Multi-domain environments

OSCP:
Import PowerView at start of AD enumeration.

ALTERNATIVE:
  $env:userdnsdomain

Time:
<5 seconds

commands.name: Enumerate Domain Controllers (PowerView)
commands.description: List all domain controllers in the current domain with IP addresses, OS versions, and roles
next_steps: Check DC OS version for vulnerabilities

troubleshooting.Unable to contact domain: DC unreachable. Check network connectivity: ping <DC>

commands.notes:
ENUMERATE ALL DOMAIN CONTROLLERS:
KEY PROPERTIES:
- IPAddress:
Direct targeting
- OSVersion:
Identify legacy DCs (2008, 2012)
- Forest:
Forest root (multi-domain)
- PdcRoleOwner:
PDC identification

OSCP:
Identify PDC from PdcRoleOwner field.
Use PDC for all subsequent enumeration (accuracy).

Time:
<5 seconds

commands.name: Enumerate All Domain Users (PowerView)
commands.description: Retrieve all user accounts in the domain with all attributes displayed
next_steps: Filter for specific attributes: Get-NetUser | select samaccountname,memberof

troubleshooting.Too much output: Filter attributes: Get-NetUser | select samaccountname,description,memberof | Format-Table

commands.notes:
ENUMERATE ALL DOMAIN USERS:
WARNING:
Returns ALL attributes for ALL users.
Output can be overwhelming in large domains.

FILTER WITH SELECT:
  Get-NetUser | select samaccountname,pwdlastset,lastlogon

LOOK FOR:
- Dormant accounts:
Old lastlogon
- Weak passwords:
Old pwdlastset
- Admin accounts:
memberof contains Domain Admins

OSCP:
Pipe to select immediately (avoid overload).

Time:
10-30 seconds

commands.name: Get Specific Domain User (PowerView)
commands.description: Retrieve detailed information about a specific domain user

flag_explanations.-Identity: Specifies the user to query. Accepts samaccountname, distinguished name, or SID. Faster than filtering all users.

next_steps: Check memberof for Domain Admins membership

troubleshooting.User not found: Verify spelling. List all users first: Get-NetUser | select samaccountname

commands.notes:
QUERY SPECIFIC USER:
Faster than Get-NetUser | Where-Object
Queries AD directly.

KEY ATTRIBUTES:
- memberof:
Group memberships (Domain Admins?)
- admincount:
1 = protected admin account
- pwdlastset:
Password age (old = weak)
- serviceprincipalname:
Kerberoastable?
- useraccountcontrol:
Account flags

OSCP:
Quickly profile high-value targets.

Time:
<5 seconds

commands.name: Find Kerberoastable Accounts (PowerView)
commands.description: Enumerate all user accounts with Service Principal Names registered (Kerberoastable targets)

flag_explanations.-SPN: Filters users with servicePrincipalName attribute set. These accounts run services and are Kerberoastable - service tickets can be requested and cracked offline.

next_steps: Identify service type from SPN (HTTP, MSSQLSvc, etc.)

troubleshooting.krbtgt showing in results: krbtgt has SPNs but is not Kerberoastable. Filter out: Get-NetUser -SPN | ? {$_.samaccountname -ne 'krbtgt'}

commands.notes:
KERBEROASTING TARGETS:
SERVICE ACCOUNT CHARACTERISTICS:
- Elevated privileges (local admin, DB access)
- Weak passwords (rarely changed)

SPN FORMAT REVEALS SERVICE:
- HTTP/:
Web servers
- MSSQLSvc/:
SQL Server
- TERMSRV/:
RDP

KERBEROASTING WORKFLOW:
1.

Request service ticket (valid domain creds)

2.

Extract ticket (contains password hash)

3.

Crack offline (hashcat/john, no lockout)

OSCP:
Most reliable privesc technique.
Enumerate SPNs early.

Time:
5-10 seconds

commands.name: Enumerate All Domain Groups (PowerView)
commands.description: List all security groups in the domain with clean output

flag_explanations.select cn: Filters output to only show Common Name (group name). Without this, PowerView returns all attributes which is overwhelming.

next_steps: Prioritize: Domain Admins, Enterprise Admins, Administrators, custom groups (IT, Service, Management)
commands.notes:
ENUMERATE ALL GROUPS:
DEFAULT HIGH-PRIVILEGE:
- Domain Admins:
Domain-wide admin
- Enterprise Admins:
Forest-wide admin
- Administrators:
Local admin on computers

CUSTOM GROUPS REVEAL STRUCTURE:
- IT_Admins
- SQL_DBAs
- Service_Accounts
- Management

OSCP:
Look for 'Admin', 'IT', 'Service', 'Management' in names.
Often have elevated privileges.

Time:
5-10 seconds

commands.name: Get Specific Group Details (PowerView)
commands.description: Retrieve members of a specific domain group

variables.name: <GROUPNAME>
variables.description: Domain group name (use quotes if spaces)

flag_explanations.-Identity: Specifies the group to query. Accepts group name, distinguished name, or SID.
flag_explanations.select member: Displays only the member attribute (group members). Members shown as distinguished names.

next_steps: Check for nested groups (member DNs starting with CN=group)

troubleshooting.Group not found: Use quotes for group names with spaces. Verify exact name: Get-NetGroup | select cn
troubleshooting.Member field shows distinguished names: Use Get-NetGroupMember for cleaner output with resolved usernames

commands.notes:
MEMBER ATTRIBUTE FORMAT:
Distinguished names (LDAP), not usernames.

FORMAT:
- Users:
CN=username,CN=Users,DC=corp,DC=com
- Nested groups:
CN=groupname,CN=Users,DC=corp,DC=com

NESTED GROUP DETECTION:
DN starts with 'CN=' and contains 'CN=Users' = likely group.

BETTER ALTERNATIVE:
Get-NetGroupMember -Recurse (auto-resolves nested)

OSCP:
Domain Admins members = instant win.

Time:
<5 seconds

commands.name: Get Group Members Resolved (PowerView)
commands.description: List group members with resolved usernames and object types (cleaner than Get-NetGroup)

flag_explanations.-Identity: Group to enumerate members for. More user-friendly output than Get-NetGroup.
flag_explanations.-Recurse (optional): Resolves nested groups recursively. Use: Get-NetGroupMember -Identity "<GROUPNAME>" -Recurse

success_indicators: Members listed with types (user vs group)
next_steps: Check for service accounts in privileged groups

troubleshooting.Group not found: Use quotes for group names with spaces

commands.notes:
CLEANER OUTPUT:
Resolves DNs to usernames.
Shows object types (user vs group).

MEMBEROBJECTCLASS:
- user:
objectClass=user
- group:
objectClass=group (nested)

-RECURSE FLAG:
Automatically resolves nested groups.
Essential for finding all effective members.

OSCP:
Always use -Recurse for privileged groups.
Find hidden admin accounts in subgroups.

Time:
5-10 seconds

commands.name: Enumerate Domain Computers (PowerView)
commands.description: List all domain-joined computers with OS information for targeting

flag_explanations.select dnshostname,operatingsystem,opera: Filters output to show hostname (for connection), OS name (for targeting), and build number (for vulnerability matching).

troubleshooting.Output too large: Filter by OS: Get-NetComputer -OperatingSystem '*Server*' | select dnshostname,operatingsystem

commands.notes:
ALL DOMAIN COMPUTERS:
No network scanning required.

KEY FIELDS:
- operatingsystem:
Identify legacy (7, 2008)
- operatingsystemversion:
Exact build for CVE
- dnshostname:
FQDN for connections

FILTER EXAMPLES:
  Get-NetComputer -OperatingSystem '*Server*'
  Get-NetComputer -OperatingSystem '*2008*'

OSCP:
Focus on legacy OS and servers.
Higher misconfigurations/unpatched vulns.

Time:
10-30 seconds

commands.name: Enumerate Organizational Units (PowerView)
commands.description: List all Organizational Units to understand domain structure and delegation

flag_explanations.select name,distinguishedname: Shows OU name and full LDAP path. Distinguished name reveals OU hierarchy.

next_steps: Identify interesting OUs: Servers, Workstations, Service Accounts
Query objects in specific OU: Get-NetUser -SearchBase 'OU=ServiceAccounts,DC=corp,DC=com'
commands.notes:
OUs ORGANIZE OBJECTS:
For management and GPO application.

COMMON OUs:
- Domain Controllers:
DCs
- Computers:
Workstations
- Servers:
Servers
- Custom:
By department/function

INTERESTING OUs:
- Service Accounts
- Privileged Users
- Disabled Users

OSCP:
Less critical than users/groups/computers.
Can reveal admin practices.

Time:
5-10 seconds

commands.name: Enumerate Group Policy Objects (PowerView)
commands.description: List all Group Policy Objects in the domain to identify policies and configurations

flag_explanations.select displayname,whenchanged: Shows GPO name and last modification date. Recent changes may indicate active admin work or policy testing.

next_steps: Find vulnerable GPPs: Get-NetGPOGroup (looks for cpassword)
commands.notes:
GPOs DEFINE SETTINGS:
- Password policies
- Software installation
- Scripts
- Security settings

DEFAULT DOMAIN POLICY:
Controls password requirements and lockout.

VULNERABILITIES:
- GPP passwords (cpassword attribute)
- Startup scripts with hardcoded creds
- Weak security settings

WHENCHANGED:
Recent changes = testing/debugging (weak security).

OSCP:
Find GPP passwords in SYSVOL.
Old vuln, still present in legacy.

Time:
5-10 seconds

commands.name: Get Forest Information (PowerView)
commands.description: Retrieve AD forest information including domains, global catalog, and forest functional level
next_steps: Enumerate all domains in forest: Get-NetForest | select -ExpandProperty Domains
Target root domain for Enterprise Admins
commands.notes:
AD FORESTS:
One or more domains in trust relationship.

SINGLE DOMAIN:
Forest = Domain (little value).

MULTI-DOMAIN:
Reveals structure and trust relationships.

ENTERPRISE ADMINS:
Exists only in root domain.
Admin rights across ALL forest domains.

OSCP:
Most exams are single-domain.
Use for multi-domain scenarios.

ALTERNATIVE:
  [system.directoryservices.activedirectory.forest]::getcurrentforest()

Time:
<5 seconds

commands.name: Enumerate All Domain Users (PowerView)
commands.description: List all domain users with key properties using PowerView

flag_explanations.description: User description field (often contains useful info like 'temp password: Winter2023')
flag_explanations.pwdlastset: When password was last changed (identify stale accounts)
flag_explanations.lastlogon: Last logon timestamp (identify active vs inactive accounts)

troubleshooting.Get-NetUser not recognized: Import PowerView first: . .\PowerView.ps1 or Import-Module PowerView.psd1

commands.notes:
CHECK DESCRIPTION FIELDS:
Admins often store passwords there.

COMMON PATTERNS:
- 'temp password'
- 'default password'
- 'reset to'
- 'password:
Winter2023'

FILTER:
  | ? {$_.description -match 'password|pwd|pw'}

commands.name: Enumerate All Domain Computers (PowerView)
commands.description: List all domain computers with OS version and last logon

flag_explanations.lastlogon: Last logon timestamp (find active vs stale computers)

commands.notes:
TARGET OLDER OS:
Server 2008, 2012 - likely unpatched.

LASTLOGON:
Identify active machines.

FILTER:
  | ? {$_.operatingsystem -match 'Server 2008|2012'}

commands.name: Find Live Domain Computers (PowerView)
commands.description: Enumerate domain computers and test connectivity with ICMP ping

flag_explanations.-Ping: Tests ICMP connectivity to each computer. Only returns live/reachable hosts. WARNING: Slow on large domains (250+ computers).

troubleshooting.No pingable hosts: ICMP may be blocked. Try without -Ping flag to get all computers.

commands.notes:
WARNING:
Slow on large domains (250+ computers).

USE FOR:
- Small environments
- Need only active targets

ALTERNATIVE:
Get all computers, then port scan.

commands.name: Get Group Members Recursively (PowerView)
commands.description: List all members of a group including nested group memberships

flag_explanations.-GroupName: Target group to enumerate (use quotes for names with spaces)
flag_explanations.-Recurse: Follows nested group memberships. If User A is in GroupB, and GroupB is in Domain Admins, User A is returned.

next_steps: Check each member's privileges on other systems

troubleshooting.Group not found: Verify group name: Get-NetGroup | select name

commands.notes:
Critical for identifying privilege escalation paths.

Nested groups often overlooked.

EXAMPLE CHAIN:
User → Helpdesk → ServerAdmins → Domain Admins

USE -RECURSE:
Finds all effective members through nested groups.
